Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Native-Language and Native-Dialect Effects in Learning to Perceive a Difficult Phonetic Contrast in Korean

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
When people learn foreign languages, there are often pairs of sounds that are difficult to differentiate. For example, many Japanese learners of English have difficulty hearing and pronouncing the difference between "r" and "l" because there is only one Japanese sound that is close to both of these English sounds. This project studies how people who are learning a foreign language might develop the ability to differentiate difficult sounds. Specifically, it looks at how native speakers of Chinese, Japanese, and English who are enrolled in intensive language courses in Seoul learn the difference between two difficult "s"-like sounds of Korean. It explores the relationship between the cues (the differentiating physical characteristics) for these two Korean sounds and the cues for the most similar sounds in the different first languages. A primary method used in this exploration is a series of perception experiments that the Korean-language students will do at 6-month intervals over their first year of extensive study of Korean. Results from these experiments will be analyzed statistically to track which cues different learners use at different stages. The same experiments will also be used to test which cues are used by native speakers of Korean from three different dialect areas, where the cues to these "s"-like sounds are not the same.

The results of the study will increase our understanding of why learning a second language is so different from learning a new dialect. This should improve second language teaching methods for difficult languages such as Korean, Arabic, and Chinese.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand how non-Koreans from different language backgrounds perceive certain Korean pronunciations compared to how native speakers of different Korean dialects perceive the same pronunciations. We specifically investigated two Korean "s"-like sounds that are known to be difficult for non-Koreans to learn, and are also reported to be difficult for native speakers of some (but not all) Korean dialects. Here, we'll call one of the sounds "sh" and the other one "s*".

Native speakers of Mandarin and Japanese who are learning Korean often report that both Korean "s" sounds sound the same. Even Mandarin and Japanese speakers who are very fluent in Korean still find it nearly impossible to hear any difference between the two Korean "s" sounds. We tested native speakers of Mandarin and Japanese who had no knowledge of Korean whatsoever, and found that the native Mandarin speakers thought the two Korean "s" sounds were differnet in certain vowel contexts: they sounded very different from each other before "a", somewhat different from each other before "i", but the same as each other before "u".

Specifically, they thought that Korean "sh" sounded like Mandarin "ts" before "a", but that Korean "s*" sounded like Mandarin "s". Native speakers of Japanese who had no knowledge of Korean, however, thought that both Korean "s" sounds sounded like Japanese "s" in all vowel contexts.

These results predicted that when native Mandarin speakers learn Korean, they should be better than native Japanese speakers at hearing the difference between the Korean "s" sounds, at least when they are followed by "a" (if not before "i" and "u"). When we tested native speakers of Mandarin and Japanese who were studying Korean in Seoul, however, we found that speakers from both populations were equally unable to correctly identify either Korean "s" sound before any vowel. Even very native Mandarin speakers who were very fluent in Korean were unable to accurately identify either Korean "s" in a perception test.

We hypothesize that the reason for the native Mandarin speakers' poor performance is that although their native language trained them to hear the difference between the two sounds (as demonstrated by the Mandarin speakers who knew no Korean), certain aspects of the Korean writing system interfered with their auditory perception. For example, basic Korean vocabulary includes many words that were borrowed from Chinese and whose pronunciations in Korean and Mandarin are still somewhat similar. Many of these Korean words begin with "sh", but very few begin with "s*". Among the Korean words that begin with "sh", many of them begin with "s" in Mandarin. This may lead native Mandarin learners of Korean to conclude that Korean "sh" is somehow similar to Mandarin "s". Another piece of evidence available to the native Mandarin learners of Korean is that Korean "sh" is romanized with the letter "s". This "sh" sound is actually the first sound in the names "Seoul" and "Samsung", which all native Mandarin learners of Korean living in Seoul would become immediately familiar with.

In our other experiment, however, we found that native Mandarin speakers who knew no Korean thought that Korean "s*" sounded like Mandarin "s". That is, there is a mismatch between auditory information and written information. According to auditory information, Korean "sh" is like Mandarin "s", but according to written information, Korean "s*" is like Mandarin "s". This mismatch may be what caused the native Mandarin learners of Korean to be so poor at identifying the Korean "s" sounds in perception.
